Finding aid for
BMC Media Services records, 1851-2003

Finding aid created by

physdesc.extent: 3 films, oversize rolled materials and oversize folders

did.abstract: BMC Media Services (formerly Biomedical Communications) is an in-house graphics and marketing production service for the University of Michigan. The collection is comprised of visual materials, including photographic prints, negatives, slides, and contact sheets, as well as videotapes, a few films, and digital files. The records reflect BMC's biomedical origins and document the history of the medical school, health science, hospitals, and related departments at the University of Michigan.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was initially received through the Historical Center for Health Sciences in 1992 (Donor 8111). Periodic additions are received from BMC (Donor No. 8110).

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: Restricted access in part; see access restrictions on following page.

The BMC record group includes restricted material in the following categories:
Student Academic Records -- removed to vault storage.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, BMC Media Services (Formerly UM. Biomedical Communications) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: BMC Media Services, formerly Biomedical Communications, was an in-house graphics and marketing production service for the University of Michigan. Owing to its medical origins, BMC Media Services was administratively a unit in the Department of Medical Education within the University of Michigan Medical School. In the mid 1960s the Medical Photography, Medical Television, and Medical Illustration units in the Medical School were consolidated to form the Biomedical Media Production Unit (BMPU). In 1983 BMPU changed its name to Biomedical Communications. By the late 1990s the biomedical aspect was de-emphasized in favor of BMC Media Services, a recognition of the broader role the unit played on campus.

In 2006, the University's two marketing organizations, BMC Media services and Marketing Communications, merged to form Michigan Marketing and Design (MM&D). Marketing Communications had provided print and Web publishing and creative service across the central academic and administrative units while BMC Media services primarily served the U-M Health System and provided video production, in addition to print and Web-based services.
Michigan Marketing and Design provides communications consulting and strategic planning; creative concept development and messaging, graphic design and production, web design and production services.

scopecontent.p: The records of BMC Media Services (formerly Biomedical Communications) measure 31.65 linear feet of visual material in a variety of formats. The records consist of seven series, largely different photographic categories: Faculty and Staff Portraits, Group Portraits, Class Photographs, Building Photographs, Topical Photographs, Films, and Videotapes.

controlaccess.head: Subjects - Visual Material:
controlaccess.subject: Health facilities--Design and construction.
Hospitals--Design and construction.
Medicine--Michigan.
Surgery.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Replacement Hospital Project.
controlaccess.subject: Medical education--Michigan--Ann Arbor.

scopecontent.p: The Faculty and Staff Portraits series (9.15 linear feet) consists of an alphabetically arranged run of individual photographs, somewhat arbitrarily subdivided by letter, and a subseries of Individual Portraits by Department, arranged alphabetically by department. The Individual Portraits by Subjects sub-series consists primarily of black and white negatives and copy prints of medical faculty and staff, both professional and administrative. BMC collected the earlier photographic material which includes some copies made from late 19th and early 20th century sources. The sub-series is arranged alphabetically by surname. There are generally more negatives than prints, and the majority are studio portraits. Many of the folders include additional information regarding individuals, such as the units with which they were affiliated at the University of Michigan. The Individual Portraits by Department sub-series consists of black and white and color negatives and contact prints, and some copy prints of medical faculty, staff, and students. In instances where separate negatives, photographs, or contact sheets did not exist for individuals, they are arranged by department. Examples of this include negative strips, contact sheets, and negatives that contain images of numerous individuals within a department. The photographic material in the Individual Portraits sub-series dates from the latter half of the twentieth century, and the majority of it was most likely produced by BMC.

scopecontent.p: The Group Portraits series (3.25 linear feet) consists of black and white and some color negatives, and color prints of medical faculty, staff, and students. The majority of the photos are from the latter half of the twentieth century. This series is arranged alphabetically by group or department

scopecontent.p: The Class Photographs series (1.5 linear feet) contains four subseries: Basic Science Students, Introductory Physiology Classes, Incoming and Current Students, and Graduation Photos, all arranged chronologically. The first sub-series consists of portrait photographs, taken between 1931 and 1963 (with numerous gaps), of medical students enrolled in introductory Physiology classes. Contact prints were subsequently identified and pasted onto paper. Roughly one-third of these portraits derive from summer sessions, and these students, for the most part, were not matriculating at the university. No negatives are extant for these photos. From 1966 to 1969, portrait photographs were taken of incoming medical students in an unknown context. In the 1990s, photographs were taken of basic science students, M4 students, and medical science students not in their final year, in unknown contexts. These photos, primarily negatives, comprise the Incoming Students sub-series.

scopecontent.p: The Graduation Photos subseries includes pictures (primarily copy negatives) of the medical school's graduating classes, taken from 1851 to 2006 (with numerous gaps). For the most part, these photos are composites of individual student portraits. However, especially in the earlier years, informal and formal group portraits were sometimes taken. Frequently, the class composites also include faculty portraits. In some of the early folders, there are composites consisting solely of faculty members. Most of the composite portraits have been identified, and the names can usually be read on the 8" x 10" negatives. The negatives were likely used to provide the set of composites lining the corridors of the Towsley Center on the medical campus. (Original composites are also located in the following Bentley Library record groups: University of Michigan. Medical School, and University of Michigan. Photographs Vertical File.) The most recent composites exist in digital format on photo CDs.

Unless noted otherwise, there is a single negative and no print for each listing. Oversized materials are located separately. The unit for the dimensions listed is inches. Unless otherwise noted, each photo is a composite of student and/or faculty portraits. Those photos designated "faculty" contain only faculty portraits. Those photos designated "group" are formal or semi-formal posed shots, with individuals usually not identified.

scopecontent.p: The Buildings Photographs series (1.25 linear feet) includes numerous black and white and color exterior and interior views of the buildings that make up the university medical complex. The series also features prints and negatives documenting the construction of various hospital structures. The most complete series of construction photographs exist for the Taubman Medical Library and the second Medical Science Building. This series also contains many images of older, medical buildings, since torn down. Photographs of the first two campus hospital structures, built in 1869 and 1875, were brought together into a separate grouping ("Nineteenth Century Buildings"), along with folders for other buildings from this period. This grouping also contains a file of miscellaneous copy negatives of drawings and photographs of the early campus. Further, the series includes numerous views of early buildings in the Catherine Street area, such as the Maternity Hospital, the Contagious Hospital and the Psychopathic Ward. The "Old Main" Hospital, built in 1925, has three folders within this series, one of which contains oversized pictures and another of which documents the demolition the building. The series is most thorough in documenting the medical building program from the late 1940s to the late 1960s. There are multiple external views and occasional construction photos of the first two Kresge buildings, the two Medical Science Buildings, the Children's Hospital and numerous others. The demolition of the "Old Main" Hospital and construction of the "new" University Hospital (Taubman Center) are well documented in the series. Significant for researchers documenting the development of university medical construction, there are several aerial views of the hospital complex (all prints, except for one color negative). One of these dates from 1964, and others were taken during the 1980s and 1990s.

scopecontent.p: The Topical Photographs series (13.5 linear feet) contains two sub-series: Medical Related photographs and Non-Medical Related Photographs. The first subseries includes prints and negatives from a variety of medical related contexts including class reunions, lectures, graduation, medical procedures, and other activities and events. The second subseries includes prints and negatives from a variety of non-medical related contexts outside the University of Michigan Healthcare system, evidence of the broadening role of BMC Media Services on campus. These prints and negatives document academic and administrative units within the University of Michigan. They include award ceremonies, class reunions, building dedications, graduations and other events and activities. Within the Topical Photographs series, academic, administrative, and medical groups and units arranged alphabetically. Within each department or unit, folders are listed alphabetically. The Topical Photographs series contains numerous photographs produced by BMC and used in various brochures, bulletins, and other publications. Of special interest are three folders that document the clinical training of students. Based on dress and other evidence, these photographs are probably from around the end of the nineteenth century. One folder of "ward photographs" taken in the old Catherine Street Hospital buildings probably dates from the same time period. In both cases, the presence of photos from the Gibson photographic studio helps to date the files. Also of note are photos from certain "historic events," such as a visit from Dr. Christian Bernard, and pictures of early heart and lung transplant operations (1968 and 1969).

scopecontent.p: The Films series consists of three outsize 16 mm films on four reels. Two of these were produced by or for UM Medical Television, and the other was produced for the Department of Prosthetics. See the contents list for additional information regarding each film.

did.unittitle: Fabrication of a Gel Socket, 16mm undated

Dr. Child performing abdominal surgery [ca. 1970] (color; approx. 30 minutes; 16 mm; silent; identified on canister as "A Roll"). Summary: Footage of abdominal surgery. Film opens with brief shot of surgeon then proceeds with incision and surgical procedures. Exact type of operation unclear, perhaps kidney surgery.

Collis-Belsey [ca. 1960] (color; approx. 20 minutes on two reels; 16mm; silent). Summary: Lecture footage and demonstrations of procedures; exact subject of film uncertain. Unknown if finished print of film exists.

scopecontent.p: The Videotapes series (3 linear feet) consists of U-matic videotapes of the "Replacement Hospital Project" documenting construction of the "new" University Hospital and demolition of the "Old Main" Hospital. Cameras periodically captured footage of construction progress and related ceremonies. This footage was compiled for possible distillation into a final overview of the entire project. The bulk of the coverage is construction of the new hospital between 1981 and 1984. Tapes include the 1986 ceremonies dedicating the new University Hospital and Alfred A. Taubman Medical Center. The 1989 demolition of "Old Main" is also recorded. The videotaping captured various viewpoints giving an overall perspective, including slow pans. Frequently, the camera focused in on surrounding locations such as North Campus or traffic along Fuller Road. During ceremonies the cameras captured crowd views and officials. Although speeches were recorded on the videotape, most are inaudible.

The videotapes contain valuable footage documenting the changing hospital landscape as well as important project officials. From a history of the construction industry perspective, the videotapes contain useful footage of the equipment and building construction methods employed in the early 1980s.

odd.p: (tape broken)
